The question seems to assume that "Scotland" can set a date for another referendum on independence. An Independence referendum is a UK Constitutional matter. Constitutional matters have not been devolved to the Scottish Parliament ("Scotland") but are reserved by the UK Parliament in Westminster. Therefore before Scotland could set a date for a referendum the Westminster Parliament would have to pass legislation authorising  it. There seems to be no appetite by the UK government to authorise another referendum. 
Therefore in order for anyone to set a date for another referendum would require (a) The Scottish Parliament to decide that there was a very high probability of winning a 2nd independence referendum (b) the Scottish government demanding that events had meant that the results of the first referendum should be ignored and request that Westminster authorise a 2nd referendum  (c) something to happen to change the UK government's mind. 
Although the UK has voted for Brexit, which could be considered grounds for holding a 2nd referendum, as yet it is totally unclear what form Brexit will be (or indeed if it will actually happen). Until it is clear what form  Brexit will take it will remain equally unclear what impact, if any, it would have on Scotland there are not really any grounds for holding a 2nd Scottish referendum.
Coupled with this the problems that are arising from having a Brexit referendum that only established what the voters did not want (they did not want to be in the EU) but did not actually establish what relationship, if any, voters wanted the UK to have with the EU. It can now be seen that there is a very high probability that having voted for Brexit, whatever relationship between the UK and EU results, a majority of voters will be unhappy with the outcome (e.g. if 48% did not want to leave, 10% want no deal with the EU at all, 10% want to be in the EEA, and 32% want some other arrangement then it will not be possible to give the majority what they want). The 1st Scottish referendum was a vague as the UK EU referendum, now with the benefit of the Brexit vote it is likely that Scottish Independence voters would want to vote for something more concrete than just leaving the UK, they would expect to be voting for a specific relationship with both the UK and EU.    
It is probable that by July 2017 it will still be unclear what the relationship between the UK and EU will be.

The obvious place to get a base rate from is the Scottish indpendence referendum held in 2014. Wikipedia says [1] the referendum started life as a bill before parliament, introduced on 21 March 2013, and passed on 14 November 2013 (so about 8 months later). Since the bill includes the date for the referendum, I assume we would say "Scotland set a date for another referendum" when another such bill *passes*, not when it is proposed. So the question is, what are the odds such a bill would be proposed and passed by 1 July 2017? Let's break this down into two questions: (1) About how long will it take for a new referendum bill to be INTRODUCED? (2) After it's introduced, how long before it's PASSED? Let's tackle (2) first. On the one hand, since the new referendum bill would be so similar to the previous one, we might predict that it will take about as long to pass, i.e. 8 months. On the other hand, exactly because it is so similar, we might predict that it will pass much more quickly, since the negotiations about the details (campaign rules, who is and is not allowed to vote, etc [2]) have already been conducted and people might agree to reuse the existing details. Let's say it takes 2 months under that scenario. On the third hand, the referendum legislation seems like pretty standard election legislation [2] so ironing out of details might not be the main determinant of how long it takes the bill to pass --- bringing us back to the 8-month estimate. I'm really unsure which scenario is more likely so I'll just average the three options to get an expected delay of (8+2+8)/3 = 6 months between the bill being proposed and passed. What about (1)? It's hard to say how long it took the SNP to introduce the bill; who knows how long they worked on it before bringing it to the floor? But a rough estimate may be obtained as follows. Scottish independence is a major issue for the SNP. The SNP first won a majority in parliament in the May 2011 elections [3] (quite dramatically) and they proposed the bill on 21 March 2013. That's a delay of 22 months. So it's unlikely that it took them less than a year to draft the bill. On the other hand, the same concerns as above might apply: one referendum bill already exists, why not copy most of it? It is literally the same referendum. Apparently the Scottish government has already "agreed to draft legislation to allow the second referendum" [4,5]. Of course, the other big factor in lawmaking is politicking. The SNP lost its majority in the May 2016 elections [6] so now they have to negotiate harder with the other parties for the funds to hold the referendum, to allow it to be held at all, etc. Finally, there is Brexit itself, the driver of this new referendum. Presumably it would make little sense to hold it before Brexit actually goes through; I imagine the Scottish people would oppose a premature referendum, so politicians won't propose one. So to the delays above one must add the delays in the invocation of Article 50. Remember, the UK referendum is not legally binding, it is merely "advisory". Article 50 is another stalemate, this time between UK & EU; the UK wants the EU to offer trade deals before it takes the irreversible step of formally leaving; the EU obviously wants the UK to formally leave, thereby losing leverage, before offering trade deals [7].
